data.Name: Wetting
data.Description: The wetting phase is the fluid that tends to spread across and adhere to the surface of the solid (rock) due to its lower surface tension with the solid compared to other fluids present. This phase is generally characterized by a contact angle of less than 90 degrees with the rock surface, indicating a tendency to occupy the pores of the rock preferentially.

data.Name: Non-Wetting
data.Description: The non-wetting phase is the fluid that does not spread on the rock surface and instead forms droplets or occupies larger pore spaces, typically due to higher surface tension with the solid. This phase has a contact angle greater than 90 degrees with the rock surface, indicating less affinity to the rock compared to the wetting phase.
